I have a theory - "Math Without Numbers".

Suppose, as a student of physics, you were asked to calculate the acceleration of at Atwood machine. For the non-nerds in the audience, an Atwood machine consists of two masses on opposite ends of a rope or string, where the string passes over a stationary pulley mounted above and between the two masses. The two masses start at equal heights. Obviously, if one of the masses is heavier than the other, the heavier mass will begin to descend due to its weight, which in turn will cause the lighter mass to ascend as the two are connected via a string over the pulley. See this diagram for clarification (Java required).

Imagine a 5 kilogram block was connected to a 2 kilogram block, and that a massless pulley was used. (This considerably simplifies the calculations for reasons I won't explain here.) Obviously, the 5 kg block would start to fall immediately. Very little explanation is needed in this case, regardless of one's engineering background.

Now, assume that the masses of the pulleys are "M1", and "M2". What happens in this case? At time t, what will be the position of the two blocks relative to their starting locations? Students of science and engineering are asked to make sense of such generalizations all the time - this is one of the most important steps to forming an experimental hypothesis. Despite being able to use exactly the same process to determine what happens in the two cases, people in general have a much harder time with the second case, where the masses are indefinite.

Despite my best efforts, I struggled to solve the second, general class of problem as easily as I could the first for many years. After finally overcoming this problem, I realize that my difficulties were rooted not in the amount, or quality of my knowledge of physics or mathematics, but rather the approach I took to physics and math. 90% or more of the power of physics as a predictive model of physical reality lies in the fact that as a mathematical model, it is subject to the endless algebra, transformation, derivation, integration, etc. that modern mathematics offers.

Until one can accept, prima facie, to an almost religious degree that math unconditionally works, the tendency will always remain to do what might be called a "physical audit" of the results. For many years, I was utterly unable to make the blind leap of faith mathematics requires, and somehow insisted that, at every step of the way, what I was doing fundamentally made sense in a way which my intellect could experientially verify. The belief that theory is always subordinate to observation/"facts" is a much deeper issue which I intend to explore in a later post.

Several lemmas which follow:

1. I believe that the frustration stemming from the need for experiential verification is quite widespread in mathematically intensive academic disciplines, and forms a gap between how most professors teach vis-a-vis how most students learn. Problems arise when an educator, especially one with an intimate, intuitive feel for the subject matter, cannot bring himself to understand why a student is having trouble grasping a concept (or cannot see that the student is having trouble at all). It seems that giving this issue due consideration in university science pedagogy would serve students well.

2. The necessary faith in mathematics is greatly fostered by using as much abstraction, as early on, as possible. By showing me that a theorem or result of a proof necessarily holds for any specific case (paradoxically, by demonstrating the results of a proof hold by using no specific case), my skepticism is greatly diminished. It is only through abstract mathematics that such a need for verification can be satiated. In a nutshell, I believe this is why I am drawn to abstract mathematics, particularly to analysis - because for the first time, I understand what I am doing, why I am doing it, and furthermore, what assumptions must hold for the results of my work to be valid. Making all assumptions totally explicit is a very difficult task indeed - what does the sentence "time flies like an arrow" mean, anyway? (Comment on this. Seriously. How do you interpret that sentence? We talk about interpretations of that sentence in the programming class I teach).

Finally, I think I understand why I used to severely dislike math, but I've come to love it: I'm just too damned cynical to think that some jackoff could be pulling a fast one on me (or at least one obvious enough to catch - but how obvious is "obvious enough"?) and I'd be none the wiser.

...A year and a half later, and I haven't changed one bit

Mark Austin, you are one of the most hilarious people that I have the pleasure of knowing, and I miss you. I'll never forget that time Kurt, you, Matt, and I were sitting in Matt's basement trying to fix his network, and try as he would, Matt just couldn't do it. Kurt mentioned some comment about high-bandwidth data pipes, and I mentioned Internet2, the experimental subset of the greater internet that happens to run Ipv6.

Matt: So what is this Internet2, anyway?
Me: It's a newer, faster internet than before.
Matt: Well, what does it do?
Kurt: Everything you want it to, Matt.
Mark: Matt, let me just put it to you like this: it's the internet, but it's back, WITH A VENGEANCE.

My journal is back, with a vengeance.

After reading Teresa's post about this past year I would have to agree that the Michigan experience is a great thing. I didn't realize how much fun it could be, as I had not gone in a long time, but I remembered - with everything from working on a broken Arctic Cat, to riding around with Teresa on various vehicles, to almost killing four girls who wouldn't shut up in the kitchen.

I don't know what all of you are doing tonight, but I hope that you all stay safe, doing whatever it is that "floats your boat". I am headed to the city of Chicago tonight with Melanie and Kathy and some other guys because frankly I can't handle another night of suburban drunkenness - the idea of simply getting wasted to get wasted has started to bore me - although this is a holiday, so if I had not have spoken with Kathy, I probably would be doing it myself :-)

A big question that I cannot help but ask, with the summer of 2002 behind me, is "Will it happen again?" I am referring to the greatness of the group that I was once a part of, over this summer. I loved it all, from Chili's, to going to movies, to sitting in the "moon chair" on TJ's back porch. I got to know a lot of people better, specifically Scott, Teresa, Mike, TJ, Jeneane, and plenty of others that are still significant, but I can't remember at this particular time.

I will remember this year most of all for my four near-death experiences. Some of them are more serious than others, but nevertheless, I came within the skin of my teeth of death four times this year. I'll explain them in order of seriousness:

1. I got into a major car accident on the way to the Evans Scholars meething on I-294. My father was driving and lost control of the car after getting hit by a truck, and after doing two revolutions across 85mph 294 traffic, we came to rest against the median of the highway. I am lucky to be alive.
2. I inadvertently set my basement on fire. I talked about this previously.
3. I could have fallen through the ice earlier this week while on a snowmobile - I am actually very embarassed about this and don't want to talk about it.
4. I was lit on fire at school. How many people has that happened to?

I'm not going to make any lists here, as they would all be very not-well-thought out, and I would end up forgetting a lot. However, for what it's worth, I will always remember the nights in Habben's pool, or the times I drove Mike's Miata and nearly crashed it each time. So, again, in response to Teresa - I'm glad that I was able to become more a part of "the Teresa crew." I look forward to a summer as fulfilling and introspective as this one was, and for a group of friends as easygoing and fun to be around as this. I want to do it again, but I'm not sure if that can ever be. Have a great new year all.

Well for all of you who weren't there tonight I went to Kristen Moffit's house. I don't even know who she is, but I went over there.

At first I wasn't sure if it was a good idea that I went, as I had to be home in a few hours and might be tempted to do something that might get me into trouble. I have to teach Sunday school and possibly work tomorrow, so I couldn't afford to do anything that I might not do otherwise.

I had a great time. However, a few things happened that I did not so much appreciate while I was there. First of all, Teresa, wherever you are when I'm writing this, I hope you know that there were a lot of people at the party that were concerned when you walked off. Scott, Travis, and me looked for you for quite a while, and pretty much everyone there was looking out for you, even those that didn't even know you as anything other than "the girl in the red shirt."

Due to the ingenuity of the civil engineer of Flossmoor and Olympia Fields (COUGH COUGH) I managed to get the Honda stuck in a ditch next to the road. It's pretty hard to do a threepoint on a like seven foot freakin wide road. Oh well, I managed, but it happened again when I was head to head with a white car and there was traffic all the way down.

Anyway, Teresa, wherever you are, I hope you get home ok.

For a long time I have thought that there is some sort of inherent benefit to associating myself with a wide range of people. Mike, Teresa and I all had this experience together in D quarter gym with the "normal folk". After today I decided that I certainly have met the unstated goal of getting to know the normal folk better.

The day started off with Melanie calling me - she had read last night's lj post and decided to take me out to breakfast at Great American Bagel. Quite interesting that she would call me at about 8:30 because she never, ever calls me before I'm up - if anything I would be out and about before she even thinks of rolling out of bed. Then I remembered, she has China jet lag, and it all came clear to me. 13 hours of time difference for 2+ weeks means that our 8am corresponds to their 9pm, and I'm sure wide awake at that time.

So I went and enjoyed my breakfast with probably the most academic-minded girl at school. I'm not saying anything about that, it being a good or bad thing, she's just #1 in our class and it's part of the point I'm trying to make. We had a great time at Great American Bagel then I got home. Next thing, went to caddy.

Let me tell you, that sure is a different bunch. Today I didn't get out caddying, mostly due to the fact that I felt like being lazy, it was a really nice day, and I'm going to make a ton of money this weekend. That settled things.

So when I broke my car key I didn't so much mind. After Derek said he would leave in a little bit, I proceeded to watch him, Andy Schumake, Shana Dolch, and Billy Bunn play about an hour's worth of cards. Derek won $8.

I then had the pleasure of riding home in the back of Derek's Nissan pickup truck. No, I most certainly do not mean the back seat of the truck, as if to imply an Asian vehicle would have more space than absolutely necessary. I mean to say that I rode in the bed of the truck, right on down Halsted street to drop off Schumake. Derek then invited me to lunch and picked up Rob Frick, the kid that just quit caddying to go work at the Delta Sonic car wash. Can't say that I agree with him 100% on that one but it's his decision.

So there I was at 2pm sitting in Arby's with Rob, Shana, Derek, eating out for the second time that day. Except this time I listened to a totally different sort of conversation. We went from Rob's mom's previous schools she had taught at, to how many kids each of us wanted (Derek none), and Derek talked about how his sister Brianna would probably be white trash in ten years. No doubt, a sad state of affairs, but what can he do about it?

We then rode back to Idlewild, after getting my key. I was honestly quite surprised by the generosity of the people I caddy with, having taken me all the way home, then back to the golf course. For some reason, a cop was sitting in the lot at Idlewild, so we had to hide behind the pavilion and Rob and Shana jumped out of the bed of the truck. I have no idea why a cop would be sitting in the north lot at Idy but they followed me out. As soon as that cop turned off of me another one picked up going down Terrace (I had to take rob home in my car so that we could be legal in front of the police). They followed me for about three blocks, and I had no idea what was going on.

I still have no idea why the cops followed me, and I agree with Rob that it's no coincidence that two cops just follow you, one after the other. Additionally, I observed about 5 cars in the lot at Cilantro's, and the one just turned out after me, as if they had been waiting. All in all, very strange, and I have no idea what to think of it.

When I look back on this day I haven't quite figured out what to think yet. I like Melanie a lot, and going to breakfast with her was great. However, I also have a sort of respect for people like Derek, who, even though I believe he treats his friends in a less than friendly manner, takes a lot of responsibility for his group. Be it that he stole even more alcohol from a party, he had an eighth of weed on him while the cops were in the lot, that he wanted to go smoke a bowl at 2pm (Rob Frick objected, saying that "I don't want to feel like a pothead smoking this early in the day"), and that he has done some things I consider ridiculously stupid, I respect the kid a lot.

Apparently, he respects me too, for he invited me to come out and drink with them that night. Honestly, I didn't expect that either, but I was lukewarm to the idea the whole time. I didn't end up doing it, in lieu of seeing Kurt Zoellick tonight and working on my projects more, but it just really interests me that in one day I have seen both extremes and can respect them both for what they are. I felt very moved by that today, and I hope others might have a comparable experience some day in their lives. TJ and Mike probably understand what I'm talking about. All I'm saying is that, there are a lot of people out there, and they all have something to say. Just listen to them, and you'd be surprised at what you might find.

I'm not sure if I should mitigate the message of this post, or if I should even post it at all. A recurring sentiment around here is that many people have opinions, and they are always changing. I just hope somebody can look at this and have it brighten their day a bit. Today started off rather badly, waking up at 10:25 when I had to caddy at 11, and my mom telling me the night before, "I can't drop you off, so you'll have to find another way of getting there." I don't have a bike, and I can't really skate there, so usually I can do the hike to idy in 35 minutes. Like I said, a hike, but I don't mind. It turned out that my father had elected to stay home from work today, meaning that he could take me there. The two of us went on over there and I found that I didn't have to be there until 12. Which, although meant that I had wasted a lot of time, we could go to Subway. First though, we went to the Salvation Army Family Store on Halsted and dropped some of the stuff from out garage sale off, cool beans. (that's judy's expression...I MISS HER) We then went to Subway to eat a proper lunch and I ate too much for little me. Even though I'm fat as hell, weighing in at 190 lbs, I still can't eat that much Tuna in one sitting. Does anyone else think they put too much Tuna on their sandwiches? 12 rolls around and I'm there...STILL early because I didn't have to be there until 12:30 - I'm kind of mad at this point because that means it's going to be hot, really hot for when I'm out there, but so be it. Today I went home and that's when my day got totally awesome. First of all, the PIC works. Imagine being asked 1000 questions about something, and if you get them all right, every last one, then you get notified. Well, my notification came today. From the power supplies, to the breadboarding, to the component selection, right on down to the program I have to write on my computer for it all to work, it all worked. This made me absolutely ecstatic because the stuff I'm doing about now I will learn about in like second year of college, so I feel special that I can do it now. I also got a major upgrade on who I will caddy for this weekend in Idlewild's biggest tournament, the Gold Putter. The Putter is held each year and represents the largest in-house tournament we hold. The tournament has a five-digit purse (at least) and the winning team gets at least several thousand dollars, cool. Anyway Tony Makarek, our club pro called my house at 9:20 tonight and told me that I will caddy for Hurowitz, Grossi, and "Arnie" Granat. Now I have basically been guaranteed $250+ for this weekend, and additionally stand a chance of winning the tournament. I decided to come out around 9:30 and check in with the guys at Matt's - Melanie called me today on the cell and she had just gotten back from her over two week China trip. I picked her up to go get a video for her brother Steve's girlfriend Hon-Hon, who lives in Taiwan (not so sure about that last part but I think) and will be over there, well, now (as I write this). I was kinda pissed off that I had to drop her off after taking her to the video store and then just taking her home, with her being on the phone all the while at family video. She felt really bad about it, too. Funny thing... The more I write, as usual, the more I convince myself that we have 1/2 of a relationship. Perhaps, for better or for worse, the part that Tony and Matt never had...the emotional part. We both treat each other with this uncommon respect and I just wonder why I even expect her to spend that much time with me,,,is that sort of expectation "illegal"? Course of action to pursue...no idea, absolutely none whatsoever, and that's saying something. So summarize I had a great day, not a perfect day by a long stretch, but pretty much everything went well and I'm ready for another just like it. Things I like: going to good concerts. area 2 will be that. vanilla coke. surprisingly good for no vanilla in it road to perdition, excellent movie. just ask mike the avoidance of drama, whenever possible. lofty, but I have to dream about something walking into COLD a/c after caddying getting gatorate from emily/krystal when caddying. cool doing technical projects. they reaffirm that I do in fact know something, and that I'm not a raving idiot having enough money to do the things i want to buying stocks when they are at a really low price (hint hint) caddying for sachs knowing that i'll probably get the evans writing to make myself happy, this really works going places alone. not sure why, watching people and talking to people i don't know makes me happy. i wrote about this before talking to people on the roof of my grandfather's house text messages on my phone, cool stuff, send me some so many other things...

Haven't felt like journaling in a while. I dunno, I just didn't think I had anything to write about. Here's my attempt at writing a coherent entry.

Tonight I went to see Road to Perdition with Adam and Mike. A truly awesome movie, I must say, so much so that Mike commented that "I want to see that again, and maybe again after that, and then some more" on the way out. It's about a poor Irish family with mob ties. Now hearing that, you'd think it was a Godfather-type crime / mob movie. Well the truth of the matter is it has some really emotional parts to it, and we also concluded that it would be equally well taken by both guys and girls. So regardless of your particular disposition towards this kind of movie, go see it, because I think many will enjoy it.

The other nights of the week have basically been run-of-the-mill summer nights. Highlights include playing Ultimate Frisbee in the Dairy Queen field, then hosing myself off because I smelt horrible. I also met Matt Kahle's cousin from Bolingbrook (not Bolingbroke, a character from King Henry, a Shakespearean play...) whose name is Silver Sterling. Now come on folks, whoever names their child that must have some issues; but I digress.

Last night Katie Barr came out with us which turned out to be pretty good. We made a late-night food run to taco bell, in lieu of going to Popeyes, both of which are GREAT places to go when you get that urge to eat a bit after dinner. I tried to eat my tacos but to no avail, as Dan likes to drive the van like a maniac. I'm amazed he doesn't flip the thing over, to be completely honest - but he would not make our ACCELERATION ZERO (sorry for that physics reference its just the easiest way to convey what I mean here) and subsequently I had a real time trying to eat my hard tacos. Damn the man

As for caddying, that's that, I work 6 days a week, usually getting out at least 5, usually more. I caddied for Sachs again today, which sort of pissed everybody off. He rolls up in a cart and says, "David, my boy, are we going today?" and I just answered, "absolutely". There were about 20 people in front of me and I just got there about 10 minutes ago, and they were all slightly pissed that I got to go out before all of them who had been sitting there for as long as two hours. I take what I get over there because everyone always tries their damndest to screw you over and you have to take the breaks you get.

I think the thing I will most remember about these days involved my giant leaps in my projects going on in this little basement. I'm trying to learn about electronics this summer and I'm making a lot of progress. Today I received a PIC programmer from the land down under, you got it, Australia. The package had kangaroos all over it and said "tick", not "check", "the appropriate boxes". "Tick here please if you want..." - who would ever think of the word "tick"? I think what I'm happiest about so far are my power supplies - I made two of them, a +5 and a +12 supply. This means I am now able to run a computer off of a car's electrical system when I please, with a bit more work.

My other cool thing I did involved my modification of the desk lamp next to the computer to serve as a power supply for my programmer. The thing didn't come with an AC adapter of anything, because I got it for cheap and they feel that if you even know how to operate it you should know how to make a power supply. Basically, I did some "modifications" to my desk lamp to make it also power the programmer. I cut some wire and drilled a small hole in the base of the lamp and tapped the transformer inside of it. Even my mom thought it was cool and she hasn't the slightest clue what it actually does. Cool.

My first project is going to be the stoplight control project. I happen to have access to an IDOT standard stoplight (don't ask me how that happened, I just have a stoplight) and I want to control the lights from a computer. That would be cool. More to come later.

Monday night I went to Jeff's house, cool, I swam that night, in lieu of going to Adam's which Teresa informed me was "a bust". I still have no idea where all of you went for those first few hours, but I suppose that will remain a mystery.

As usual the length got a bit out of control but I don't post often, so deal with it. (I mean that in the most friendly sense possible). I'm really looking forward to Area 2 and I still have tickets. Please people, I'm willing to cut deals on these things AT A LOSS TO ME because I can afford it and I'm going to lose a lot of money if I don't get them sold. I'm asking about $50 for a $65 ticket - let me know if you're interested. Otherwise I'm going to lose a LOT of money. I think I can find people to go but if you want to go, please tell me.

Things I have: a sense of accomplishment, enough money for now, happy parents, siblings that aren't home
Things I don't have: a girlfriend, a car, Judy, Melanie, Shoshana (one N!) , Jenny and numerous other cool girls like Andy that just ditched the town, ticket buyers, a watch with a functional band

night all

Well not so much has happened over the last few days. Even though that is true there still have been some memorable moments.

Wednesday was the famed Sklare outing at Idlewild Country Club. This old man named Mr. Sklare brings like 25 of his friends out to just play some golf. Everything they buy goes on his tab and he spends the afternoon riding around in a golf cart just visiting with people and having a great time with everyone catching up and making small talk. I wish that some day I will have the free time, and the good health, to be able to ride around in a golf cart and talk to my friends all day. What a cool guy.

That night we went miniature golfing, and Kurt beat me. ugh

Thursday morning started with breakfast with Teresa, Baker's Square. That was really nice because I never see the girl anymore and frankly, I like her a lot. Although, after thinking about it, Teresa, I'm not so sure I think your Mayer idea is so good, but I hope it works out all right. Teresa I hope you have a great time doing that tomorrow (or is tomorrow Warped Tour? dates are starting to fly by me here) but just don't get lost or anything. I know you'll have fun.

Thursday was Sachs for the caddying, and it rained in little droplets all day today. Sachs is getting better. It's great that he actually takes my suggestions on how to improve his game. He is the kind of guy that tends to get very angry when he plays less-then-perfect golf. I told his wife one time that she needs to make him calm down, and it's saving him strokes. This is at least the fifth time I have caddied for the guy this year and I like him a lot.

While out that day, I found a bottle of Sky Blue on the course on the 15th hole. It was right over by the famed hole in the fence that Teresa and people always talk about, by the grounds grafting area, where they have a huge square section of fairway grass that the Mexicans use to replace large sections of damaged grass. There I saw it, way over in the trees there (Sachs had just hit a mean hook on 15, the dog-leg left) and the bottle was ditched under a tree. I also observed various other bottles over there. My thoughts immediately shot to all of you, although I could be wrong on that I suppose. I still do not know who put the Absolut in the pond on 17, perhaps I will never know.

Kristen Rooke and I had plans for tonight, sort of, but they never happened because I couldn't answer the phone, I was busy cleaning about 200 golf balls for the garage sale we had on Friday.

The garage sale went rather well, for a Friday morning, and I suspect that we might get more business later, because Saturday is a weekend after all. 

I tried to call Jeneane today, as you are leaving tomorrow to go back to Florida and I very much want to see you before you leave. I left a message on your voice mail in Florida with the number you gave me, perhaps you will check it. At any rate, I didn't see you tonight and I really wanted to.

Which brings me around to tonight. We decided to go miniature golfing but directionally impaired people led the pack. At one point Kurt got out of the other car in Ford Heights and a large black man in the car next to us remarked, "funna get ky'lld" when Kurt had to run back to the car, having missed the change. Even though Kurt was running back to the car on a green light, nobody honked, which surprised me a lot.

I tried to make my power supply circuit today but failed. Try again tomorrow. Persistence and confidence are key to everything.

Now I will write to Judy at her Jewish work camp - Meytiv - then go to bed. I miss her a lot.

Wow, I had no idea that it was your birthday Jenine, happy birthday! I want to see you before you leave so be sure to call me tomorrow, because I think the 27th is fast approaching.

Yes TJ, it sure is funny how power makes you popular. Almost like you go from zero to everybody's best friend in no time. Image that.

Sunday was rather longish, the last day of the caddy week. I watched a movie at Dan's house called Hart's war. The entire movie is about a guy getting court-marshalled to create a big distraction. In some ways, it reminded me of Twelve Angry Men. By the way, I know that Dan hates that movie solely on the premise that the entire thing takes place in about two scenes, but I think it's a great movie, and if anyone would be up to watching it again I sure am game.

I spent Monday at Purdue with my dad. Overall my experience impressed me. I learned that with over 38,000 students, next year they will not have a single TA teaching, period. It will be all faculty for the lectures, and several PhD students for the "recitations", in which the students have a chance to go over homework and ask questions. I learned that almost a quarter of the students there attend the college of engineering, and that the entire campus will have 802.11b (wireless networking) access by April of next year. I could talk more about the greatness of the school, but I will cease - just know that they sure impressed me when I went and I have decided to give more weight to the possibility of going there after high school.

Tuesday - today - I didn't have to caddy so I decided to have a relaxing day. I played with my electronic toys for a while in the basement and finally figured out how to send text messages to users of other cell networks, yay. 

Today Matt picked me up accompanied by Shoshana and Dan. I went to Matt's house and washed the Blazer and his dad's Miata. While there, I partook of many interesting activities, including:

1. Melanie called me on my phone while I jumped on Matt's trampoline. Quite impressive considering that where she is, it was 7:29am and it was 6:29 pm here. I think that was the earliest she had gotten up in a long time. I felt very special that someone would take the time to call me from halfway around the world.
2. We washed the cars, and because of this favor, Matt's dad let me drive his car. Miata. 
3. I convinced Matt, by not squealing the tires, stalling the car, misclutching the car, or doing anything even remotely resembling bad driving, that Nick Engel needs to shut his pie hole about my "bad driving". I am getting better at stick all the time, as I have driven seven manual cars now (although two the same make and model) and am doing better all the time. Two Miatas, Kyle's Saturn, the Echo (sorry TJ), Nick's Civic (only briefly), Dustin's Geo Metro, and my personal favorite, the VW Jetta.
4. I ate ribs. Pretty good but too much fat on them. Thanks Mrs. Kahle.
5. We convinced Matt's dad that putting an intercooler in the car is necessary.

I did a lot of electronics stuff and blew up some things today, including a 220 uF electrolytic cap. It went with a bang and a thin column of smoke started to rise out of it. Cool stuff, $.99 down the drain, oh no. 

Rounded the night off with miniature golf, Kurt beat me. Ouch. I still want to go to a Cubs game, a waterpark, and maybe Great America, so someone throw that together. that's it for today

Well I still got tickets to area 2, and so far it's Heather, Jenny, and me for sure. I'm about 90% on Melanie but she's not back yet and it's all downhill from there. Dana, George, (and dana for mike), Jessica Kraus, and a few others have expressed interest but the first four of us are pretty hardcore set on it so we're going. Well the main attraction of the last few days has undoubtedly been Homewood Days, the three-day semi-ripoff of Oktoberfest in good old Germany. In fact, I even learned how to ask for beer in German yesterday but I'm not going to try to remember it because I will screw it up, bad. Thank you Idlewild members. Which reminds me, I need more money, because I need to continue in my geeky ways and get a PIC programmer for $109. There are other things I need but this job isn't paying so well. I think that after I get the Evans (and I WILL get the evans) I will caddy for weekends for one more summer than I am done, forever, and I won't miss the place one bit. Amen to that. Last night I had a long talk with Teresa about my values and I think I just made a little bit more sense of life. I think I want a group of friends that are all aligned with my stances on things. However, she says that I am too unique to ask for that. Generally being called unique is a good thing, at least where I come from, but I think in this case the struggle for uniqueness may have harmed me. I want to be more like an average person while still continuing to be David. The last few days I have questioned what role I play in social settings. What am I working for? The American dream - perhaps I will someday get to go to college for free and save my family that much money so that they can put another two kids through college and live comfortably.

However, all of this does not change the fact that I can't even go to my lake house with my family, because I decided to stay home and work. To right all of this, I decided that I would do something I have not done in a while: get into random mischief with Amar. So we got into Amar's Lexus ES250 and headed over to ofcc. No attendant on duty, and we just drove right in and went to the range. I stopped at Cabana to get a drink and rolled out of that place. Now I'm sitting in my house with two cars and nobody here. My parents really, really don't want me to be here but I am regardless, writing on livejournal because I'm probably not going to get another chance to before family time.

In case you don't know, I am going state park-jumping with my family for this next week. From Monday to Friday I will be out of Homewood but still in the wonderfully hot, humid midwest with my family. However, also consistent with the conversation I had with Adametz last night, these trips make me grateful that I have siblings, specifically my brother, to make it more bearable.

In the mean time, my parents are at our lake house and I am staying with my grandparents on Oak Street in Chicago Heights.

Last night, I decided to go to Habben's house. The only problem is, I didn't have a car, so I walked from the Heights to Adam's house. It took me 1:04 which is pretty good time for that distance. On my way there, I stopped and helped two black guys down the block from my grandparents hook up their Rockford Fosgate sub box. I also saw a bunch of Mexican kids al yelling Spanish at each other playing soccer in Bloom Field. All in all, I enjoyed myself, and took in more of "the culture". Perhaps that's why I'm worthy of getting a "thug life" sticker slapped onto my shirt while I read slashdot and watch spaceballs amongst other things at Adam's house.

I'm not sure what I want to do tonight. Per Lani, my guys are back from Michigan today I guess, so I may go out with them. However, Teresa still owes me 1/5 of a Buca dinner so maybe I'll be getting some free (well prepaid at least) ice cream tonight. Perhaps I even will go out and get into more mischief with Amar and Dan. (someone call me at 755-0751, gp's phnum)

My only hope, for the moment, is that college comes before I can get much more depressed, and I can think about how I don't have to pay for it and be happy. As Brian told me, I went into the basement to get either a new bit for the Rotozip or maybe a hand saw to finish a cut I was working on. I reached onto my father's workbench and happened to knock a metal right-angle tool off the wall. Basically, the metal tool is a ruler with a metal piece affixed to the top of it at a right angle to help you draw corners and make lines exactly perpendicular. The important point is that it is fairly massive (about 2-3 kg) and has sharp corners. Wouldn't you know, the metal tool fell off the wall and knocked a can of White "American Satin" Rust-Oleum spraypaint off the workbench and onto the floor. The metal tool then got caught for a split second on the corner of the bench. Right about at this point, I dived over and tried to catch the can, but I couldn't get there in time - and then the right-angle tool fell exactly onto the can, corner first, in a way such that the can split open. As I look at it now, the hole in the can is only about as big to allow a drinking straw through. My immediate thought was to get a paper towel off the roll next to the sink in the basement of my house, because this white paint-mass was oozing out of the can and covering the floor. The aerosol agent was spraying everywhere into the air, and the more dense white paint was forming a huge puddle on the floor. I didn't get too worried because I thought of glue and ink, and they don't dry and make such a mess when they are in big blobs, as long as you clean them up. It's been about 10 seconds since I split the can open and I turned around to get a towel. However, the smell of it all was excruciatingly bad, so I took to opening the window above my father's workbench as wide as it would open. I wanted to get as much of that smell out of the house as possible. I climbed up the edge of the bench to open the window, when... BOOM was the sound I heard, followed by immense heat, a blinding flash of light, and a pressure blast of magnitude sufficient to knock me off my father's bench. At this point I turned around and realized that there was a six-foot high fireball 18 inches from my right knee. I was mostly surprised that this had all happened. Mostly, I was just like "wow that thing is freakin huge". So I started to walk away from it, but as I walked, the flames followed me. I think this was either due to the high concentration of chemicals I still had on me, or maybe the air current that was created when I started to walk at rather high speed away from it. As soon as I got away from the fire, I ran up my back stairs as fast as I could. I said calmly "I need a fire extinguisher" amidst my family's bewildered looks and questions of what had happened to cause the explosion that they had both heard and felt, two floors away. I grabbed the fire extinguisher, ran back down into my smoke-filled basement, and emptied the contents of the extinguisher onto the flames. I went upstairs and told everyone briefly what had happened. My father then placed a fan at the foot of the stairs to air the smoke out. I went back downstairs to make sure nothing was still burning, because for all I know, the flames could reignite any second - fuel, heat, and oxygen were still all there. I found the corner of the white shag carpet in the basement glowing red, and stomped it out immediately. My dad then called the fire department. It has been about 2 and a half minutes since I first knocked the can over, and I went outside to tell Brian what had happened, and to GET FRESH AIR. The mixture of smoke and whatever all else was down there had done a number on my lungs, and I felt somewhat light-headed. No later than 1 minute after we called, we heard sirens and horns. A little bit later, five engines had shown up at my house. My neighbors came out, and saw an ambulance rushing to the scene. They also saw a Homewood Police car. My brother commented, "must be a boring night" due to the fact that the dispatch was clearly overkill, given that the fire had already been extinguished. They stationed 2 trucks in front of my house, and then another one evenly spaced down to where Howe avenue intersects my street - all the way down to Ed's house. All they had to do was place these huge fans in the house and ventilate it all out. They also brought out all the burn[ing][t] stuff in my basement and put it next to the back door. The paramedic on the scene insisted that I get treatment, so I went into the ambulance and breathed oxygen for about 3 minutes. They took my pulse, blood pressure, and listened to my heart and breathing. I was ok. It's amazing how long you can hold your breath when you're inhaling pure oxygen - one minute was no problem at all for me. That's about all for that, except that a fireman had to come back because he had left his helmet in the basement on the workbench - "oops". I also received a call from fire chief Ray Presnak (I've known him from church for about 5 years) saying that the chief on the scene said that my actions with the extinguisher probably saved the entire basement, if not the house. He called me to tell me I did a good job. I felt good about that. So then, with my singed eyebrows, I headed over to the book burning at Mike's house. Question of the day: How much is your time worth? Kurt originally suggested this question to me, but I expounded on it enough tonight to write a journal entry about its significance to my life tonight.

I realized today, that a reason why all my friends sometimes fight with me, is because I insist on planning for every little contingency. Every little problem that could go wrong, I try to anticipate in advance.

Then I thought about the way most Americans live their lives, and I discovered the truth in one of my father's highly extremist statements that he makes sometimes that you can't do anything but laugh about. I think one time in a big rampage about people not planning and screwing things up he said that "The only reason Fedex exists is because people can never get it together." Today, though, I thought about if people really even need to ever get it together in today's world.

My family insists on planning everything so that we can save the greatest amount of money. In case any of you don't know, I come from a three-generation tradition of cheapness which is an artifact of the depression I think - but it just never left the family, and my father takes pride in his cheapness. When I thought today, I realized that there are two basic ways of living life - you can either value time or money. Most of the time, people that have a lot of one don't have a lot of the other to enjoy. Just think about this for a minute:

About 2 months ago I had to spend like 3 hours in the car running around to get a bunch of papers signed. In the morning my dad was really irked that I had used a lot of gas, and he had to stop because he wasn't sure if he could make it to work that day with the gas in the car, subsequently making him late.

I admit 100% that fault of my dad being late to work is on me. The thing that I realize though, is that my parents and I live under totally different ideologies. They live more of the money-commodity life, and I think that I have more of a time-commodity view of things. Simply put, I could have avoided this mess by planning more, but if we had more money, I could simply buy a car and things would be all ok - I wouldn't have to take my dad's car.

Like I often do, I thought for a while about my new idea - time vs money - and realized that given any problem in life that has a solution, there is probably another solution under the other mindset. If plane tickets are too expensive, this implies that you don't have enough money - so spend more time looking for tickets in advance of the flight, or stand at the airport and wait for really good deals on underbooked flights. On the same note, if you don't have enough time to cook a decent meal, which probably means you have money because it seems like that's always the case - you just order something.

The reason why this is important to me is because I have isolated another point of friction between my parents and me. My family operates on the idea that money is scarce, and time is plenty - and so much stuff makes sense when viewed through this framework - my dad always complains that he has to fix the house but he does it anyway - and it seems like my dad goes out of his way to do things in the most difficult way when he could just work more and pay someone else to do it. I am more the opposite - and I think people, at least the ones that I think about when I make this comparison - are being raised to believe in the "time commodity" view of life. I wonder what the merits of either are, and what factors make either come out?

I think that the American way favors spending money to get more time - we have too much money but not enough time. Throw up some responses to this - I'm curious - what frame do you and your family operate in, and do you think I'm right when I say that most Americans favor having a lot of money and then spending it to get more time?

-your wannabe philosopher friend, dave
